name: Olga Cemetery

sections.heading: Memories by Jane Barfoot Hodde
sections.content:
Copied from a letter from Jane Barfoot to the Olga Community Club, circa November 1991

Olga Cemetery was established in the early 1890s on property donated by William and Sarah Moore. This 210-foot square was a reasonably open area on the upper part of the Moore homestead, but there were many large trees that were taken out through the years. Prior to 1900 there had been less than ten burials recorded.

Richard C. Willis (my grandfather) platted the cemetery, with the plat having been recorded May 4, 1906 in Friday Harbor. The deed (which was for many years kept with the Community Club secretary's books but which was such an interesting document that "someone" caused it to "disappear") that needed to be cut; the area was in very bad condition at that time and a date was set for a work party with the women furnishing the dinner. Thus was started the tradition of the "Cemetery Picnic", a highlight of the year when the entire community would meet on a date set near Decoration Day—entire families working together, then at noon a long table in the alder grove below the cemetery was spread with all kinds of good food and a general feeling of fellowship.

Other ways Olga has been indeed as a community were several summer picnics on Carlson's beach, and the annual Thanksgiving dinner in the old dance hall—a picture is in the display cabinet in the corner of the Energetic Club House. The lady sitting on the platform with the musicians is the only known photo of Sarah Moore, according to her granddaughter, Marjorie Reed Klingman, of Anacortes, whose mother was Ella Moore, younger child of William and Sarah.

The Moore family gave Doe Bay Community the lower section, making it the Olga/Doe Bay Cemetery. The Ladies Energetic Club headed the work parties. In the early 1950's seventy people were present for dinner and a meeting at the Club House, after working all morning in the cemetery. Mrs. George (Ethel) Loomis was presiding officer. A mower was purchased for anyone to use, providing their own gas.

When the Community Club was organized in 1958-59, the ladies asked them to take over the supervision of the cemetery. In 1967 the State Department of Game furnished wire for fencing in a special program when damage from deer was widespread. Fence posts were donated; the Club bought gates and Burial Hall was hired (mostly donated) to complete the fence in 1962. Thurman and Joe Bond took over from Bill Moore as coordinator of grave location and work. Glen Rodenberger and Murl Johnson replaced old lot markers that had been broken or were nonexistent. There were many unmarked graves. Ralph Pinneo cemented the first fifty markers that work together and give to our neighbors and friends the same feeling we ourselves would wish.

Bill Moore kept records, mostly in his head, of most of the early burials; Mr. Loomis started a book of the locations, which is still being used. My mother, Louise Willis, was Sexton, or record keeper, from 1937 to 1954, when she turned it over to me. It was very important that these records be kept up to date, as many people come seeking information of their forebears. Also state laws say all burials must be recorded.

All funds must be kept for maintenance and expense as the monies have been given specifically for that purpose.

I would urge anyone in the Olga/Doe Bay Area who feel they might wish to be buried here to reserve a space, so that when the time comes there is not the stress of choosing. Space is becoming limited; therefore, we have endeavored to restrict burials to those who own property or have requested space earlier when they lived here.
sections.source: 125 Years: Olga: Memories and Potlucks (Compiled by Irene Barfoot O'Neill)
